poem:
Title: Vignette of Vision

Ratcatcher– 
a cinereal landscape 
painted by a Glasgow hand.
Young Lynne's artistry,
an orange amid the ochre.
A testament, solid 
like gold standard,
etched in celluloid skin.
Realist cinema–
Social realism's comet tail,
passionate as Loach,
pensive as Davies.
A canvas of dreams,
a hallucination in daylight.
What was, 
is now remembered
in her haunting debut.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Ratcatcher review – Lynne Ramsay’s haunting debut is a hallucinatory wonder Twenty-five years ago, we saw one of the most impressive debut features in modern British movie history. Ratcatcher, by the 29-year-old Glasgow film-maker Lynne Ramsay, was a visually haunting, passionate piece of work to compare with Terence Davies or Ken Loach and which set a gold standard of artistry for new social realist cinema – or cinema of any sort – in the UK.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Ratcatcher review – Lynne Ramsay’s haunting debut is a hallucinatory wonder Twenty-five years ago, we saw one of the most impressive debut features in modern British movie history. Ratcatcher, by the 29-year-old Glasgow film-maker Lynne Ramsay, was a visually haunting, passionate piece of work to compare with Terence Davies or Ken Loach and which set a gold standard of artistry for new social realist cinema – or cinema of any sort – in the UK.
